text: Patient: I haven’t had chemo there. Doctor: But I’m talking scans. Patient: Scans. Yeah I’ve had scans at Hospital B and also Hospital C at O____ and also the Hospital A, so in M____. So you know it doesn’t make any difference really to me, yeah. Doctor: Great, I just want to make sure that they can be compared so that we can get a sense of what’s changed- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because if everything’s stable even though your PSA is going up, we might wait longer. If the pictures show more cancer and your PSA is higher Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter) Doctor: How you feeling? Patient: I’ve been great. Doctor: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Now, in March, you were at two and a half. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. text: Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor: Different than the one he’s on. Yes. Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials?

text: Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving?

text: Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay

text: Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast. Patient: Man. Man, that was so bad, so bad. Doctor: So, Patient: I did it twice on myself, man. ‘Cuz I went out, and I had to catch the bus back home. Man, it’s like I had to walk home ‘cuz I didn’t want to get on the bus. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They’ll be saying, “What’s that smell like shit.” Doctor: Hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
